Subject. German subsidised Steamers, for Africa.
Consular Bureau JAN 8 1901
No. 56. Consular, Legation of the United States, Monrovia Liberia; Nov. 30, 1900.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.

Sir: Touching the importance of the African trade, in European markets, especially in Germany, I have the honor to enclose, for the information of the Department, three clippings, from a London periodical, relative Central African Commerce.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant, Owen L. W. Smith, M. R. and C. General
148 CENTRAL AFRICAN COMMERCE AND TRANSVAAL TRADER. October, 1900.
GERMAN SUBSIDISED STEAMERS TO SOUTH AFRICA.

A copy has been received at the Foreign Office of a précis by the Commercial Attaché of the British Embassy at Berlin of the explanatory statement annexed to the German Bill regarding the extension of the German subsidised steamers to South Africa. The memorandum states that it is not intended to enter into direct competition with the fast steamers of the Castle and Union lines, but the intention is to place the German ships on a par with the so-called "intermediate boats," which, on the West Coast of Africa, travel at about eleven knots, and reach the Cape in twenty-two days. A fortnightly service right round Africa will be established, starting alternately to the east, through the Suez Canal, and to the West by the Canary Islands. The ports called at will be as follows:-

On the eastern voyage: Hamburg, Bremerhaven, Antwerp, Lisbon, Naples, Port Said, Suez, Aden, Tanga, Zanzibar, Dar-es-Salaam, Mozambique, Beira, Delagoa Bay, Durban, East London, Port Elizabeth, Capetown, Las Palmas, Lisbon, Bremerhaven, and Hamburg.

On the western voyage: Hamburg, Bremerhaven, Amsterdam, Lisbon, Las Palmas, Capetown, Port Elizabeth, East London, Durban, Delagoa Bay, Beira, Mozambique Dar-es-Salaam, Zanzibar, Tanga, Aden, Suez, Port Said, Naples, Lisbon, Rotterdam, Bremerhaven, Hamburg.

It has been decided not to call at Swakopmund, in the German South West African Protectorate, as it would be deviating from the direct route. On the round voyages between Europe and the Cape, the contract rate of speed is to be twelve knots, both for ships already afloat, and for the new vessels still to be built for the African services, when on the West Coast of Africa. The speed in the East Coast will be the same between Napes and Dar-es-Salaam, whereas, on other stretches, it is only to be ten and a half knots, as at present. A branch line, with regular fortnightly connections is to be established between the ports on the East Coast of Africa and Hamburg, via the Suez Canal, as far as Beira. For the carrying out of the above services, in the proposed extended them, the East African line is to receive and Imperial subsidy of $67,500 per year, of £22,500 more than it now has under the existing contract: the duration of the new agreement is to be for fifteen years. The financial position of the East Africa line, in spite of the subsidy of £45,000 a year, was by no means satisfactory in the first years of its services to the East Coast of Africa. The capital originally, was £300,000; there were large deficits for several years, and in 1894 the capital was reduced to £250,000, £50,000 being written off as lost capital. In 1895 there was no deficit: in 1895 and 1896 6 per cent was paid; and in 1897 and 1898 3 per cent was received by the shareholders.

The future traffic requirements will be: the two large steamers now ready, five new large steamers still need to be built at a cost of £125,000 each, and four medium sized intermediate vessels costing each £65,000
It is proposed that the new contract should come into force on April 1, 1901.
PROPOSED NEW RAILWAS IN SOUTH AFRICA.

In the course of a most interesting letter to the Morning Post, the Hon. Robert White deals with the present position of South African railways and the lines on which future developments will most probably take place. He gives a list of suggested new lines, which is worthy of reproduction here. They are as follows:-- 1. Harrismith to Bethlehem (fifty-five miles), thence to Heilbron. As already mentioned, this line is partly commenced. It would connect Natal with the Orange River Colony trunk railway, and open up the grain district. 2. Vereeniging to Johannesburg direct (thirty-five miles). 3. Kimberley to Bloemfontein (100 miles). 4. Kimberley to SPringfontein, via Fauresmith and Jagersfontein (130 miles). 5. Winburg to Ficksburg and Harrismith (120 miles). Would supply Bloomfontein, Kimberley, and the Transvaal from the grain districts. 6. Aliwal North to Wepener, thence to Ladybrand, Ficksburg, and Bethlehem (190 miles). Would run right through the rich grain districts of the Orange River Colony. 7. Springs to Middelburg (eighty miles). A very necessary line, as it runs through the coal districts, and could supply Johannesburg. 8. Klerksdorp Fourteen Streams (150 miles). This is the old road from Kimberley to Johannesburg, and would open up coal and gold districts. 9. Poort to Leydsdorp (150 miles). About seventy miles is already laid (Sela Railway). 10. Pietersburg to the Gwanda Railway (250 miles). Would connect Johannesburg and the south directly with through the Transvaal.
AFRICAN PERSONALITIES.
Mr. W. Gilmore, of Wilson and Gilmore, Capetown, has concluded his stay in England.
Mr. W. F. Leeson leaves very shortly for Durban in the interests of the Natal-Zululand Railway.
Mr. W. Traill Anderson, chairman of the Kimberley Chamber of Commerce, returned to the Cape of the 15th ult.
Mr. Abe Bailey, one of the most active of the Rand millionaires, has been spending a brief holiday at the Hotel Majestic, Harrogate.
Mr. C. H. Perrott, of the famous Tenter Street firm, Perrott and Perrott, has arrived at the Cape on an important business tour.
Mr. J. S. Apsey, of Johannesburg, has returned to the Cape preparatory to fresh enterprise in the wholesale import line at the Rand.
Mr. J. L. De Jongh is in London. He is one of the most indefatigable of the executive members of the Rand Chamber of Mines.
Mr. J. Frank Brown, the newly-appointed Postmaster-General of Natal, left London for Durban on the 15th ult. in the Dunvegan Castle.
Mr. Phillips will again represent the interests of the Namaqua Copper Co. at the Cage next month. He sails in the Briton on the 20th inst.
Mr. Robert Williams, of Tanganyika Concessions and Zambesia Exploring fame, is back in town immensely the better for his holiday in Aberdeenshire.
Mr. C. Lepper, editor of the TImes of Natal, is on a holiday visit to London. Mr. C. Woodhead, editor of the Natal Mercury, returns to Durban on the 20th inst. in the Briton.
Mr. Fritz Mosenthal, one of the principals of the great Algoa Bay, East London, and Transvaal import firm (Messrs. Mosenthal and Co.), returned to South Africa in the Scot on the 22nd ult.
Mr. E. T. Boxall, who represents Van Den Berghs, Ltd., at the Cape, left thither on the 1st ult. in the Kinfauns Castle. He will also represent C. Farre, Rheims, the big champagne firm.
Mr. J. A. Timmis, whos "Nas" food has been one of the main constituents of "Tommy's" dietary throughout the campaign in South Africa, left in the Scot on the 22nd ult. for Capetown.
Mr. Loubser, of the important wholesale house of Messrs. Hirsch, Loubser, and Co., Algoa Bay and Johannesburg, has joined the increasing rush of Anglo-African merchants returning to Johannesburg.

On his return to England from America, Mr. R. H. Henderson, ex-Mayor of Kimberley and head of the large drapery firm there which bears his name, lost very little time ere he sailed again for South Africa. He booked by the Tantallon Castle on the 29th ult.

Mr. F. Eckstein, of "The Corner House," Johannesburg, returned to the Cape in the Norman on the 8th ult. in the full expectation that when he landed, as he would do on Tuesday last, the war would be over, and his immediate return to the Rand possible.

Mr. H. W. Markham, of the large Capetown and Johannesburg firm of that name, left for South Africa by the Tantallon Castle on the 29th ult. Mr. Edwin Greenacre, of Messrs. Harvey, Greenacre, and Co., London, Durban, Pietermaritzburg, and Johannesburg, saild by the same mail-boat.

Mr. L. L. Michell, general manager of the Standard Bank of South Africa, has come to England with some very important suggestions regarding the financial future of South Africa. He is practically the Cape Treasurer-General (Sir Gordon Sprigg's alter ego), as regards the public finances of theh Cape Colony and Rhodesia. His design for the new South African sovereigns to be minted at Pretoria is an excellent one--the Queen's head on one side and the arms of the four colonies quartered on the reverse.

Prominent figures in THrogmorton Street almost every day since their arrival early last month have been Mr. Julius Jeppe and Mr. "Cor" Rissik, of Johannesburg. The former is a member of a famous, and let it be said very progressive, German family, the heads of which were the founders of the important Johannesburg suburb of Jeppestown. Always favourites on the Rand Stock Exchange, Messrs. Jeppe and Rissik were very reluctantly "Comandeered," but took the earliest opportunity of inviting the British to arrest them as prisoners of war and place them on parole. They hope soon to be back again on the Rand, where they will be certain to work loyally under British rule.
Americans and Germans are already at work in South Africa;

As a proof that very low rates pay the promoters of these lines, it may be mentioned that when the "Chemins de Fer Economiques" reduced their minimum charge by one-half, the number of passengers in the first month increased by 60 per cent.; the receipts also increased in spite of the reduction.

The lines in the Fayoum Province, which are managed by a purely Egyptian Company, have been too lately op[ened to permit of any fair comparison being made between them and the older railways. Their receipts, however, already average £142 per mile per annum.
The Delta Light Railway receipts have increased to £245 per mile per annum and the maximum obtained on the "Chemins de Fer Economiques" has reached the figure of £280 per mile.

The rolling-stock of all these lines is as yet quite inadequate to carry the cotton and other goods brought to them. When this defect has been remedied, a proportionate increase in their receipts may be expected. There seems to be no likelihood whatever of the Government being called upon to pay the guaranteed rate of interest.
There is as yet no indication that these lines compete seriously with the State railways. The earnings of these latter have not diminished, as it was at one time thought probably would be the case.

Trade and Commerce in 1900.-- The total value of Egyptian exports from 1st January to 30th June of the current year is calculated at £E8,978,489, as against £E7,058,468 during the corresponding period of last year, that is to say, an increase of £E1,920,021.

The whole of this increase is more than accounted for by the export of cotton and cotton seed, but against this there has been a diminution of upwards of £E135,000 in the value of the sugar exports, which suffered from the failure of last year's Nile flood.

The total value of Egyptian imports, including tobacco, from 1st January to 30th June is calculated at £E6,083,896, as against £E4,998,398 during the corresponding period of last year, that is to say, an increase of £E1,085,498.

There has been an increase in the value of the imports in every one of the fourteen categories according to which they are classified, with the sole exception of "chemical products," which have slightly fallen off owing to the development of local soap manufacture.

The most notable features of this increase are to be found in-- £E (a) Cereals............................... 215,717 (b) Textiles.............................. 243,263 (c) Metals and machinery........172,834 (d) Coal and wood................... 149,177

The increases under (c) and (d) must of course be attributed in some measure to a rise in price, but the marked general development of the import trade under every head is indicative of a higher standard of comfort, together with an increased spending power throughout the country.

British trade has benefited by upwards of half a-million out of the total increase of £E1,085,498 in the imports, as against some £E100,000 credited to France and Russia respectively, £E170,000 to the Turkish Empire, and £E30,000 to Germany.
Conclusion.

The progress of Egypt's commercial development in the last decade has been marked. The total trade in 1888 was valued at £18,629,000, and in 1899 it had reached £27,495,000, and of this total trade England commands over 45 per cent.

The great wealth of Egypt lies in her agricultural resources--cotton, oil seeds, sugar, and other crops. These, in turn, depend on the Nile flood. With the Nile regulated and controlled by the immense system of reservoirs and dams now under construction, with a fellaheen freed from excessive taxation, and with a network of light railways rendering the produce of the country accessible to foreign markets, it is to be hoped that the prosperity of Egypt will show the same steady increase from year to year.
MINING PROSPECTS IN ZULULAND.
AN ADMINISTRATOR'S FORECAST.

A CENTRAL AFRICAN COMMERCE representative had an interesting chat with Major Hignett, Resident Magistrate of 'Mqutu, Zululand, just prior to his return, on August 23, to Durban, en route for his magistracy after six months furlough in the home country. Major Hignett has served both the Imperial and the Natal Governments in Zululand, first as an officer in the mounted police, and latterly in a judicial capacity, continuously for the last eighteen years. His knowledge of that part of South-East Africa is accordingly both intimate and valuable, especially as his views are also those of a thoroughly impartial official.
Major Hignett is, if anything, astonished that people here are so apt to overlook the excellent chances for voluntary white immigrants with some capital, small or large, which Zululand offers.
Major Hignett is, if anything, astonished that people here are so apt to overlook the excellent chances for voluntary white immigrants with some capital, small or large, which Zululand offers.

"In the first place," he said, "Zululand is a great mineral country. You come across minerals of all sorts wherever you go. But for the war we ourselves living on the spot would not have realised, perhaps, the valuable character of the deposits. But what the war did for Zululand was briefly this: Up to last October only second-rate mining men, with no financial backing to speak of, in most cases, and some quite amateur prospectors had been over the ground. But when the exodus (compulsory) from Johannesburg drove the firstclass-the solid-mining engineers and financiers as refugees to Pietermartizburg and Durban, they found in Zululand a territory where they could employ their enforced leisure, and the result has been that many of them are not only surprised, but also so satisfied with the results, so they assure me, that immediately they can get back to their headquarters at the Rand, they will finance and organise the thorough exploitation of numerous properties.

"Now," continued the Major, "that is not all. Besides the gold there is the coal, at St. Lucia particularly. To the new mines there, an extension of the Durban-Tugela (the Natal North Coast) railway is already being taken in hand; and along the coast-line which it will tap the possibilities for sugar and tea-planting are as good as, if not better than, those which have proved so successful lower down the coast-line in Natal proper. You have then, mining and industrial, not to mention the usual pastoral and agricultural, openings of great importance and promise in a country where the land is still all Crown land, unalienated as yet to private individuals, but which will be so alienated in the same way as Natal has been, as soon, no doubt, as the Commission appointed by the Government for the purpose, and which but for the war would have probably ere now concluded its labours, can get to work. The native tribal locations or reserves once makred off, the Ministry of Natal, to quote their Proclamation of two years ago on the subject, wish to arrange, at no distant date' (i.e., as from November, 1898), for 'the beneficial occupation by Europeans of suitable vacant land on the coast, more particularly in proximity to the proposed railway extension from the Tugela to St. Lucia coalfields, and also lands in the neighbourhood of townships either existing or to be established.'"
FRENCH SOMALI COAST
SURTAX ON SPIRITS.

The French Dé pêche Coloniale of the 2nd ult. contains a notification to the effect that spirituous liquors produced in or imported into the French Somali Coast Protectorate are to be subject, in virtue of a Decree of the Governor, to a tax of lfr. 40 centimes per hectolitre and per degree. This tax is to be independent of any Customs duty which may be established on spirituous liquors of foreign origin.
But they must make their names known to those who do the business.

RHODESIAN MINES. Crushing Returns.
ANTENIOR (MATABELE).-- Cable from the mine:--"August crushing--Mill ran twenty-four days nine hours: crushed 880 tons, gold 584 ozs." (equal to 13.27dwts.).

GEELONG.--Output for August:--"Forty stamps, twenty-eight days, twenty-one hours; crushed 3,770 tons; gained 951 ozs., equals 5.05dwts; working expenses, 14s. 3d. Hope able to haul from better ore 4th level east during latter part September." (July yield 878 ozs.)

GLOBE AND PHOENIX.--The directors have received information from the mines that the mill ran twenty-four days during August, crushed 5,907 tons of ore. Duty 6.12 tons per stamp; yield 4,742ozs., equal to 16.36dwts. average; tailings, 5.82dwts. Profit £12.911. Working expenses, £6,059, being exceptionally few owing to 70 percent. ore coming from dumps, labour being same. Value of gold, £4 per ounce.

LOMAGUNDA DEVELOPMENT.--Cable from consulting engineer dated Salisbury, September 11:--"Bore hole, eastern end of property--Cut reef. Actual width reef formation, 60ft.; vertical depth 300ft. This proves payable character reef this depth. August test crushing. 373 tons--226ozs.; value, nearly £900. Tailings, 5dwts; average value ore crushed, 17 1/2 dwts."

SELUKWE.--Crushing return for August:--"Ran twenty stamps, 29.39 days: crushed 2,644 tons, produced 1,596 ozs. of gold (equals 12.07 dwts. per ton). Tailings assay, 2.86dwts. per ton." (July yield, 3,094ozs.)
WEST NICHOLSON.--August output:--"Ten stamps, twenty-nine days eighteen hours; crushed 1,010 tonsl gained 506ozs., equals 10.02dwts. Working expenses, 25s. 2d." (July yield, 519ozs.)
SELUKWE.--A cablegram has been received from the mine advising that the full battery of forty stamps is now running.
UNITED RHODESIAN GOLD FIELDS.--Cablegram from the general manager, dated September 5:--"Inez reef--Struck main saft 250ft. levell strong. All work progressing well."

CHARTERED GOLDFIELDS.--Old Nick Property--Extract from the consulting engineer's (Mr. Franklin White) letter, dated Bulawayo, August 30:--"The mine is opening up well. Assays are nearly completed. At present the results are as under:--200ft. level--200ft. length of drive sample: average width, 3.12 ft.; average assay. 29.6dwts. 300ft. level--30ft. length of drive sampled; average width, 5.85ft.; average assay, 13.27dwts. The rich point in
200ft. level was not reached in the 300ft., neither is the full width of reef exposed in either level. The portion not sampled may be of lower value, but still of good working gold contents."

MATABELE PROPRIETARY MINES.--The consulting engineer reports that development work has been commenced on the Superb claims, Gwelo district, on which there is a splendid line of old workings, and the prospects of finding a payable reef are very favourable. Two winzes are also being sunk on the Seahorse claims, Selukwe district, on a line of old workings. He has also laid out work on the Sebakwe claims, Gwelo district, and the reef where exposed is 5ft wide. There are on the property three of old workings on the three reefs. WOrk will also shortly be Commenced on the Yatala claims (an extension of the Surprise property) in the Selukwe district.

RED AND WHITE ROSE GOLD.--Extracts from manager's report for quarter ending July 31:--"Main shaft--Driving has been started east and west. Third level reached 26th inst., at 411ft. The extent of ground broken, however, has not been great enough to have brought about any decided change with reference to the reef. The width at third level is somewhat greater than that shown where the reef was broken at second level; the width is probably, however, local. Third level--Driving is in progress east and west along the reef. Second level--East drive--This drive has been carried a distance of 205 ft. In fae of this drive the reef is well defined and of good width, but indifferent value. The average of ore exposed is 5.6dwts. over 33.4in. West drive--This drive has been carried 164 ft. The reef exposed has been of good grade for 94ft. In face of this drive the reef is of good value and well defined: the average of ore exposed is 13.7dwts., over 28.7. In segregating ore exposed on this level, following results are obtained:--West drive, 50ft. 10.2dwts, over 47.9; east drive, 44ft., 22dwts., over 32.9. No. 1 rise west-- This rise has been carried 11 ft. The reef shows a width of 38ins., the last sample taken at 10 ft. being 38dwts. No. 1 west winze--Twenty feet started 100ft. west of shaft. Reef shows width 20ins., and is well defined; average value of ore is 8.4dwts, over 26ins. No. 1 east drive--This rise has been carried a distance of 18ft., and will connect with No. 1 cast winze on first level. In the breast of this rise the reef shows a width of 72ins., but value from pannings has been low. No. 2 east winze has been started in breast of this winze. Reef shows width 42ins. First level No. 1 winze west--The reef throughout this winze has shown a favourable width of fair value. The average value of ore exposed is 9.7dwts., over 44.2ins. Footage to date:-- Main shaft, 411ft.; vertical shafts, 453ft.; drives, 1,836ft.; crosscuts, 233ft.; winzes, 153ft.; rises, 24ft.; total, 3,110ft."
TRANSVAAL MINES.

WINDSOR CONSOLIDATED.--Extract from mine manager's report to August 9:--"Main shaft has been sunk to a total depth of 109ft. The crosscut has been driven 4ft. in very hard country, and will open up the reef at the 100ft. level, giving us large quantities of stone. No 1 shaft, north stope--Ground broken 5ft. by 5ft by 3ft., total 30ft. Seven feet of timber erected and passes formed. Levels are now all in order and ready to send stone to the mill. I will take care that the development work is kept well in advance, but there is no lack of stone for the mill. I have not done a great deal of development work of late, but, now that we have the steam, I will push on with the sinking in the main shaft, as I am sure much richer ore will be got at a depth."

CUSTOMS DUTIES IN THE EGBA TERRITORIES.
DETAILS OF A NEW WEST AFRICAN TARIFF.
It is announced that the following regulations of Customs duties upon goods imported into and exported from the Egba Territories from and up to the Colony of Lagos came into force on August 1 last:--

1. From and after August 1, 1900, there shall be levied, collected, and paid to the Egba Government upon such goods, imported into and exported from the Egba Territories, as are inserted and described respectively in Schedules I. and II. hereto, the several duties of Customs as the same are inserted and described and set forth in the said Schedules.

2. The said duties shall be payable in the case of goods imported or exported by the Ogun River at the Custom House at Isheri, and in the case of goods imported by the Lagos Government Railway at the Custom Houses at Otta, Ifo, or Aro Wharf, and in the case of goods imported or exported by the man road from Abeokuta to Lagos at the Custom House at Otta.
3. No person shall import goods into or export goods from the Egba Territories into or from the Colony of Lagos except through the Custom Houses.

4. All persons importing or exporting goods by the Ogun River shall call at the Custom House at Isheri and declare the quantity and particulars of the goods which he is importing or exporting, and forthwith pay the duties leviable thereon.

5. No canoe or vessel of any description in which goods are being imported or exported shall proceed a hundred yards beyond the Custom House at Isheri until the duties leviable upon such goods have been paid.

6. All persons importing or exporting goods by the Lagos Government Railway shall, on arrival at Aro Wharf, Ifo, or Otta, as the case may be, forthwith take all goods in their possession to the Custom House at such place, and declare the quantity and description of such goods, and forthwith pay the duties leviable thereon.

7. All persons importing or exporting goods by the main road aforesaid, shall, on arriving at Otta, forthwith take all goods in his possession to the Custom House at Otta, and declare the quantity and description of such goods, and forthwith pay the duties leviable thereon.
8. No goods upon which duties are leviable shall be taken from a Custom House until the duties leviable theron have been paid.

9. The Customs officers, or any person acting on their behalf, shall be entitled to search canoes, and also to open and search all packages, loads, and boxes whenever they have reason to suspect that such canoes, packages, loads, and boxes contain goods upon which duties leviable under these Regulations have not been duly paid.

10. Every person requiring a receipt for the duties which he pays may have the same upon furnishing the officer of Customs, or person acting upon his behalf, to whom the duties have been paid, with a paper containing particulars of the goods imported or exported, and the duties paid, such list, after being examined and signed by the Officer of Customs, or person acting on his behalf, shall be delivered as a receipt to the person requiring it.
11. Any officer of Customs, or person acting on his behalf, may detain any person committing, or suspected of having committed, an offence against these Regulations.

12. Every person concerned in importing goods contrary to these Regulations, or evading, or attempting to evade, the payment of duties, shall forfeit treble the value of the goods, or a penalty not exceeding £100, or, in default of payment within three days, shall be subject to forfeiture of the goods and to imprisonment for a period not exceeding on year with hard labour.

13. Every person making a false declaration, or obstructing any officer of Customs, or person acting on his behalf, shall be liable to a penalty not exceeding £25, or in default of payment within three days, to imprisonment not exceeding six months with hard labour.

14. All disputes between importer and exporter and any officer of Customs, or any person acting on his behalf, and all offences against these regulations, shall be tried by the Alake or by the person appointed by the Alake and Council to deal with such matters.
15. These regulations shall not apply to goods in transit.
There are now, it is stated, no less than 175 miles of light railways open in Natal.
PORTUGUESE EAST AFRICA.
TONNAGE DUES.

Rhw Liabon Gazette of August 16 contains an Order to the effect that in view of the representations of the Mozambique Company, and the Consultative Committee of Foreign Affairs having been heard on the mater, it is decreed in terms of Section 11 of Article 7 of the Decree of May 17, 1897, as follows:--
